verb.description: Move at a speed faster than a walk, never having both or all the feet on the ground at the same time.
examples: the dog ran across the road
she ran the last few yards, breathing heavily
he hasn't paid for his drinks—run and catch him

verb.description: Pass or cause to pass quickly or smoothly in a particular direction.
examples: the rumor ran through the pack of photographers
Helen ran her fingers through her hair

verb.description: (with reference to a liquid) flow or cause to flow.
examples: a small river runs into the sea at one side of the castle
she ran cold water into the sink

verb.description: Extend or cause to extend in a particular direction.
examples: cobbled streets run down to a tiny harbor
he ran a wire under the carpet

verb.description: (of a bus, train, ferry, or other form of transportation) make a regular journey on a particular route.
examples: buses run into town every half hour
Andrea runs her own catering business
an attractive family-run hotel

verb.description: Be in or cause to be in operation; function or cause to function.
examples: the car runs on unleaded fuel
a number of peripherals can be run off one SCSI port

verb.description: Continue or be valid or operative for a particular period of time.
examples: the course ran for two days
this particular debate will run on and on

verb.description: Be a candidate in a political election.
examples: he announced that he intended to run for President

verb.description: Publish or be published in a newspaper or magazine.
examples: the tabloids ran the story
when the story ran, there was a big to-do

verb.description: Bring (goods) into a country illegally and secretly; smuggle.
examples: they run drugs for the cocaine cartels

verb.description: (of an object or act) cost (someone) (a specified amount)
examples: a new photocopier will run us about $1,300

verb.description: (of a stocking or pair of tights) develop a vertical line of unraveled stitches.

noun.description: An act or spell of running.
examples: I usually go for a run in the morning
a cross-country run

noun.description: A journey accomplished or route taken by a vehicle, aircraft, or boat, especially on a regular basis.
examples: the New York-Washington run

noun.description: An opportunity or attempt to achieve something.
examples: their absence means the Russians will have a clear run at the title

noun.description: A continuous spell of a particular situation or condition.
examples: he's had a run of bad luck

noun.description: A widespread and sudden or continuous demand for (a particular currency or commodity)
examples: there's been a big run on nostalgia toys this year

noun.description: The average or usual type of person or thing.
examples: she stood out from the general run of varsity cheerleaders

noun.description: A sloping snow-covered course or track used for skiing, bobsledding, or tobogganing.
examples: a ski run

noun.description: An enclosed area in which domestic animals or birds can run freely in the open.
examples: a chicken run

noun.description: Free and unrestricted use of or access to.
examples: her cats were given the run of the house

noun.description: A point scored by hitting the ball so that both batsmen are able to run between the wickets, or awarded in some other circumstances.
A vertical line of unraveled stitches in stockings or tights.
A downward trickle of paint or a similar substance when applied too thickly.
The after part of a ship's bottom where it rises and narrows toward the stern.

phrases: he had only to snap his fingers, and she would come running
Every once in a while he has flings but when Michelle crooks her finger he comes running.
It drove her mad that I didn't come running when she snapped her fingers.
I don't know how you do it, but whenever you crook your little finger, we all come running.
Bobby Orr was single then, and all he had to do was crook his finger and the girls would come running.
I just thought you might have run across him before
In the Czech Republic, like any non-Anglo region of the globe, one frequently runs across amusing mistranslations of English.
She has to be one of the most annoying characters I've ever run across.
I've been a private eye for thirty-five years, give or take, and I've never run across anything like this.
She said that while overall she enjoys her job, she still runs across people who like to grumble or to ridicule her.
origin: Old English rinnan, irnan (verb), of Germanic origin, probably reinforced in Middle English by Old Norse rinna, renna. The current form with -u- in the present tense is first recorded in the 16th century.
